description:
From David Black on bug 885167:

One more possible bug (I don't know if this is reachable) is that the tarfile.extractall method is used in the
 static method _untarzip_image. This method is also vulnerable to path traversal (as per the warning in the tarfile module documentation).

Filing this here for further investigation.
title: Potential directory traversal in _untarzip_image

comments.content:
From David Black on bug 885167:

One more possible bug (I don't know if this is reachable) is that the tarfile.extractall method is used in the
 static method _untarzip_image. This method is also vulnerable to path traversal (as per the warning in the tarfile module documentation).

Filing this here for further investigation.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~ttx

comments.content: We should definitely protect against directory traversal here... I'm pretty sure you can inject a malicious tarfile in the EC2 image upload process.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~ttx

comments.content:
Proposed fix, nova-core please pre-review before we make it public.
Adding stable maintainers. Once this is pre-approved we'll coordinate disclosure.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~ttx

comments.content: Can you include a test to make sure we actually plug the hole? Include a "malicious" tarball in the tests directory (remember to add it to MANIFEST.in) and run it through this routine.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~soren

comments.content: Attached version including tarballs and test
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~ttx

comments.content:
Issue looks valid to me - we can't trust what users upload to s3/objectstore

Fix looks fine too - it's a bit odd to open the file twice, but the alternative of doing something like tar_file.fileobj.seek(0) is just too hacky. Also, no attempt is made to explicitly close the file if there's an exception, but that's true of the original untarzip_image() code too

So, yeah - lgtm too
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~markmc

comments.content: lgtm.  We might want to refactor into a specific exception later, but lets keep the patch small for now.
comments.author: https://api.launchpad.net/1.0/~vishvananda
